Mass. R. Civ. P. 17(a)\u2013(c).proposition: At all relevant times, Mr. Johnson brings this action on his own behalf for economic losses and on behalf of J.J. as parent and next friend pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 17(a)–(c).

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, in that Plaintiffs seek damages within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court arising from a tort committed within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant is organized under the laws of Massachusetts and/or regularly transacts business in Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Brockton District Court under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the cause of action arose in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts, where Defendant’s community center is located and where the incident occurred.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 50–52 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant, acting through its employees, agents, and/or servants, owed J.J. a duty to exercise reasonable care to supervise him and to protect him from foreseeable harm while he was in its after‑school program and under its control.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a dissent focused entirely on proximate cause and foreseeability in a college’s security measures regarding a rape, not on the existence or scope of a duty to supervise or protect a specific individual in an after‑school program. The opinion (especially this portion) does not discuss duties arising from custodial relationships with minors or program participants, nor does it articulate a general rule that a defendant, through employees or agents, owes a duty to supervise and protect someone under its control. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific duty proposition claimed.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving 'that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.' Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969)."

Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 12\u2013.proposition: Defendant, acting through its employees, agents, and/or servants, owed J.J. a duty to exercise reasonable care to supervise him and to protect him from foreseeable harm while he was in its after‑school program and under its control.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 12\u2013.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that a defendant running an after‑school program owed a duty to use reasonable care to supervise and protect a child in its control. Wallace v. Wilson concerns a parent hosting a teen party at home and explicitly holds that, as a matter of law, the parent owed no duty to third parties to supervise the minors’ drinking where she did not provide or make alcohol available. The case therefore rejects, rather than affirms, a supervisory duty in an analogous setting and does not support the claimed duty of care in an after‑school program context.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 12\u2013.relevant_excerpt: “We reject the argument that a parent, who neither provides alcoholic beverages nor makes them available, owes a duty to travelers on the highways to supervise a party given by her minor child. We reach this conclusion even if [the defendant] knew or reasonably should have known that alcoholic beverages would be available. The defendant’s conduct did not create a risk of injury to the plaintiff for which we are prepared to say the common law should provide a remedy.… We continue to adhere to the rule expressed in Langemann, and we think that that rule should apply here.”

Flood v. Sargent, 366 Mass. 99, 103\u201.proposition: Children under the care of youth programs and community centers are invitees to whom the operator owes a duty of reasonable care, including supervision appropriate to their age and vulnerability and to the risks inherent in the activities being conducted.
Flood v. Sargent, 366 Mass. 99, 103\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case about ineffective assistance of counsel in an armed robbery prosecution. It does not discuss premises liability, invitee status, youth programs, community centers, duties of care, or supervision of children. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition regarding the duty owed by operators of youth programs or community centers to child invitees.

Panagakos v. Collins, 80 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Panagakos v. Collins, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 697, 700–01 (2011)
Panagakos v. Collins, 80 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant owed J.J., as a minor child lawfully on its premises and enrolled in its after‑school program, a duty to exercise reasonable care to supervise him and to protect him from unreasonable risk of physical harm.
Panagakos v. Collins, 80 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a commercial lease dispute, personal guaranty, and mitigation of damages between a landlord and a restaurant tenant. It does not involve a minor child, premises liability, duties of supervision, or protection from physical harm. Nothing in the holding or reasoning addresses the duty owed to a minor child in an after‑school program or any analogous duty of care, so the case cannot support the stated proposition.
Panagakos v. Collins, 80 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The defendant Walter Collins (Collins) leased property for his restaurant business, McWal, Inc. (McWal), from the plaintiff, Michael Panagakos, for several years. During the course of renegotiating the lease, Collins gave Panagakos a personal written guaranty. A little more than a year later, the restaurant closed and the defendant left the premises with three and one-half years left on the lease. Panagakos sued Collins to recover for breach of the written guaranty and to set aside a fraudulent conveyance of real estate between the defendant and his wife.

Commonwealth v. Welansky, 316 Mass. 383,.proposition: A special relationship existed between Defendant and J.J. because Defendant undertook to provide care, custody, and supervision of J.J. in its after‑school program, thereby assuming responsibility for his safety during the hours of program operation.
Commonwealth v. Welansky, 316 Mass. 383,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a special relationship arising from an entity’s undertaking to provide care, custody, and supervision of a child in an after‑school program. Welansky deals with a nightclub owner’s criminal liability for manslaughter based on a duty of care owed to business invitees on premises he controlled, not with custodial or supervisory relationships over children or program participants. While it recognizes a duty to business visitors, it does not address or establish the specific type of special relationship described in the proposition, so it does not support that claimed principle.
Commonwealth v. Welansky, 316 Mass. 383,.relevant_excerpt: “[W]here, as in the present case, there is a duty of care for the safety of business visitors invited to premises which the defendant controls, wanton or reckless conduct may consist of intentional failure to take such care in disregard of the probable harmful consequences to them or of their right to care.” (316 Mass. at 397)

Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..raw_text: Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289, 291–93 (1988)
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..proposition: Defendant also had a duty to exercise reasonable care in the hiring, training, supervision, and retention of its staff responsible for supervising children in the gym, so as to ensure that those employees were competent and attentive to child safety.
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The case expressly recognizes a common-law duty of an employer to exercise reasonable care in the selection and retention of employees who will come into contact with the public, and upholds a verdict on a negligent retention theory. While the facts involve a bar rather than a children’s gym, the legal principle is general: employers must use due care to avoid hiring or retaining unfit employees where they interact with invitees. That directly supports a claimed duty of reasonable care in hiring, training, supervision, and retention of staff responsible for supervising children.
Foster v. The Loft, Inc., 26 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The doctrine states that an employer whose employees are brought in contact with members of the public in the course of the employer’s business has a duty to exercise reasonable care in the selection and retention of his employees. These principles have been explained in the following manner: ‘An employer must use due care to avoid the selection or retention of an employee whom he knows or should know is a person unworthy, by habits, temperament, or nature, to deal with the persons invited to the premises by the employer.’”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.proposition: A reasonably prudent operator of an after‑school program in Massachusetts, under like circumstances and with knowledge of the mixed ages and number of children present, would not have permitted unsupervised or minimally supervised rough tackle play in a gymnasium, and would have taken steps to stop such play immediately upon notice.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a premises‑liability/negligence and statutory‑violation claim arising from a scaffolding collapse at a residential construction site. It does not involve after‑school programs, supervision of children, or rough play, nor does it discuss the standard of care for operators of youth programs or gymnasium supervision. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for what a reasonably prudent after‑school program operator in Massachusetts would do regarding tackle play or supervision.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty….”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.proposition: Defendant’s failure to use reasonable care in supervising and protecting J.J. from foreseeable harm constitutes a breach of its duty under Massachusetts common law of negligence.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.support_reasoning: The case recognizes and defines a duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts negligence law for a homeowner in Kask’s position, but it does not hold that Kask (or any defendant) actually breached that duty. The SJC reverses summary judgment only on the duty issue and explicitly leaves to the jury the question whether Kask’s conduct amounted to a breach. Thus, the opinion supports the existence of a duty, not the proposition that failure to supervise and protect J.J. was a breach of that duty.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.” (447 Mass. at 147-48)

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to use reasonable care in supervising and protecting J.J. from foreseeable harm constitutes a breach of its duty under Massachusetts common law of negligence.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that a defendant’s failure to use reasonable care in supervising and protecting J.J. from foreseeable harm constitutes a breach of its duty under Massachusetts negligence law. Davis v. Westwood Group holds almost the opposite in this context: it finds that the landowner (Westwood) owed no duty to protect the plaintiff from harm on an adjacent state highway and expressly limits any voluntarily assumed duty to the narrow task of hiring police officers, which it concludes was performed with due care. The case does restate general negligence principles (duty, breach, foreseeability, voluntary undertaking), but its holding declines to extend a duty to supervise or protect against the third party driver’s conduct; it therefore does not support the proposition that such a failure constitutes a breach here.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. … It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … In this case, Westwood did not fail to exercise reasonable care in the use of its land… The mere fact that Westwood’s facilities used land on both sides of Route 1A… does not necessarily impose on it the broad duty to provide safe passage over the State highway… This we decline to do.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639–41 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The harm to J.J. was reasonably foreseeable: children rough‑housing and tackling on a hard gym floor, especially when older and larger children are involved with younger and smaller children, presents an obvious risk of significant injury.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the harm was reasonably foreseeable. Thus, this opinion segment does not support, and in fact contradicts, the asserted foreseeability proposition.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: There were no superseding or intervening causes sufficient to break the causal chain between Defendant’s negligence and J.J.’s injuries.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case holds the opposite of the claimed proposition. The SJC explicitly finds that later actions by the INS—particularly its 1995 release of MacNeil—constituted a superseding cause that broke the chain of proximate causation between the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence in 1987 and the officer’s 1995 injuries. Thus, Kent is authority that there WAS a superseding/intervening cause sufficient to break the causal chain, not that there was none.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “Because the duty to prevent harm, and the risk created by MacNeil’s release, were transferred to a law enforcement agency that could lawfully be relied on to perform safely the responsibilities it had assumed, the element of proximate cause, which might otherwise have linked MacNeil’s release on parole with his harmful conduct in Leominster, was extinguished. Subsequent action by the INS releasing MacNeil in Massachusetts became a superseding cause of the harm he inflicted, relieving the Commonwealth of liability as a matter of law.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6D, J.J.’s injuries constitute a “serious injury,” including at minimum medical expenses in excess of the statutory threshold and impairment of bodily function.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85L.proposition: Mr. Johnson, as J.J.’s parent, has incurred medical expenses on behalf of his minor son in the approximate amount of Five Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($5,500.00), and may incur additional medical and related expenses in the future.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 85 & 85K.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 85 & 85K, Plaintiffs seek full compensatory damages for all injuries and losses caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to: medical expenses; lost wages and lost earning capacity (if any); pain and suffering; loss of enjoyment of life; and any other damages allowed by Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence defenses are raised, Plaintiffs affirmatively state that J.J., as an eight‑year‑old child, cannot be held to an adult standard of care and did not act unreasonably under the circumstances.

Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681.raw_text: Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681, 691–92 (1989)
Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence defenses are raised, Plaintiffs affirmatively state that J.J., as an eight‑year‑old child, cannot be held to an adult standard of care and did not act unreasonably under the circumstances.
Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681.support_reasoning: The case involves teenagers aged sixteen and eighteen and does not discuss the standard of care for an eight‑year‑old child, or how a child’s conduct is evaluated in comparative negligence. The discussion of capacity and awareness of risk is limited to whether these teens were ‘too immature’ to appreciate danger for purposes of trespasser exceptions, and the court expressly notes plaintiffs admitted they were not such immature children. The opinion therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that an eight‑year‑old cannot be held to an adult standard of care or did not act unreasonably.
Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs admitted that neither of the decedents was a child too immature to discover the dangerous condition or to realize the risk involved in his conduct. See McDonald v. Consolidated Rail Corp., 399 Mass. 25, 31 (1987). Compare Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 378 Mass 177, 182 (1979); G. L. c. 231, § 85Q.”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: Defendant is liable for the negligence of its employees, agents, and/or servants under the doctrine of respondeat superior, as those individuals were acting within the course and scope of their employment at all relevant times.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a corporate employer (here, a medical practice group) is vicariously liable under respondeat superior for the negligence of its physician employee when the alleged negligence occurs within the scope of that employment. The court rejects any special control requirement for physicians and states that, once employment is shown, the only remaining question is whether the act was within the scope of employment—precisely matching the proposition that the defendant is liable for the negligence of its employees acting within the course and scope of their employment.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. Once employment is established, the only remaining issue is whether he was working for BMA at the time of the alleged negligent treatment, i.e., whether his treatment of the plaintiff was within the scope of his employment by BMA. This comports with traditional agency law that ‘[a]n employer is liable for torts committed by employees while acting in the scope of their employment.’”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiffs statutory interest on any judgment from the date of commencement of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7\u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Award Plaintiffs their taxable costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 et seq.;

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiffs hereby demand a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
